linkedin_essay.text:
Before examining why this matters at civilisational scale, let us be honest about why so many people are not having children, or are having fewer than they say they want. The barriers are not imaginary. They are structural, measurable, and in many cases getting worse.

In 1970, the average house in the United Kingdom cost approximately 3.6 times the average annual salary. Today it costs roughly 8.3 times. In London, the ratio exceeds 12. In Sydney, 13. In Vancouver, 12. In Munich, 11. These are not marginal increases. They represent a fundamental restructuring of what young adults can afford.

You cannot raise three children in a one-bedroom flat. You struggle with two in a two-bedroom flat. Yet for millions of young couples in Western cities, a three-bedroom home â€” the bare minimum for a family of four â€” requires either inherited wealth, two high incomes, or a move to a town where neither partner can find work in their profession. Housing policy is fertility policy, whether governments acknowledge it or not.
